author: DAVID BOROFF
title: Imprisoned ex-Yankee Chad Curtis says he has $39
text:
Chad Curtis appears in Barry County District Court in Hastings, Mich, in 2012. Albans, Mike Chad Curtis celebrates his walk-off homer in the 1999 World Series. Previous Next Enlarge 
From hero to near zero. 
Imprisoned former New York Yankees World Series star Chad Curtis told a Michigan judge on Monday that he has "$39 in my personal account" and "9 noodles in my cell," MLive.com reported . 
The 46-year-old ex-baseball player told Judge Ellen Carmody that he can't afford to hire an attorney for a civil suit brought against him by four women who say they were sexually assaulted by Curtis when they were high school students. 
"I think you may be penny-wise and pound foolish" by not hiring a lawyer, the judge told him, according to MLive.com. The judge also said a recent 103-page filing made by Curtis was "weak." AP Chad Curtis is serving a 7-to-15 year prison sentence. 
The former major leaguer did say his wife is funding his criminal appeal, the Michigan news website reported. 
Curtis, who is serving 7-to-15 years for assaulting three of the young women, was also admonished by the judge for trying to publicly identify the three women . 
"I realize I was wrong. I apologize. ... I don't want to make mistakes," Curtis said via video link. "I apologize for that mistake." 
The plaintiffs have asked for summary judgment against Curtis in the civil suit. Lawyerless, Curtis is mulling a countersuit. 
"I know the truth is on my side," he told the judge, MLive.com reported. "I do not believe there will be a large verdict." 
Curtis played with the Yankees for three years during his 10-year Major League Baseball career, hitting a walk-off homer off the Braves in Game 3 of the 1999 World Series.
